So each vector runs at a constant frequency and tip to tail it approximates the SVG inputted. All deterministic values calculated from a unit integral. That's mind blowing.

I wonder if we could calculate the minimum set of frequencies to generate a particular image? Right now we use the integers, but maybe there's a smaller set in the rational numbers.

Another question I thought was interesting is, how does a linear transformation of the image affect its fourier representation? I'd imagine these to be continuous wrt to linear transformations. E.g. if you do a shear transform by some angle, there is an upper bound on how much the underlying frequencies changed.

Finally, what if we allowed the frequency to be variable too (it wouldn't be as elegant, but it would be pretty interesting to look at)

I had the unfortunate displeasure to learn Fourier while being integrated in other subjects from non-mathematicians. I learned the transformations, some of the rules and that you can make any periodic curve with enough sinusoids but I never learned the intuition behind it. I think that now I am STARTING to understand the principle behind it: complex numbers in essence being rotational vectors, combining enough of those rotating vectors (and maybe a few constant vectors) with different rotational frequency and length to draw any figure and after one period it starts again at the same place for the entire figure. So what causes the areas with the greatest deviations between the desired and plotted curves, and what does this tell us about that area of the curve?  Starting very simple a circle or an ellipse or hyperbola can be plotted with almost no deviation.  But is is not just smooth changes in the slope of the curve that explain deviations because sharp points like in the Seattle skyline are plotted precisely as well as smooth curves.  The Fourier series has to plot the entire figure, so maybe if the rate of slope change--slope acceleration--is common within the figure there will be better precision in matching the desired curve.  But even areas with an unusual slope acceleration visually seem to plot with small deviations if the change in slope acceleration--slope jerk--is low.  So my best guess is that if the slope acceleration is unusual within the figure and the slope jerk is high, there will be an area of higher deviation from the desired curve.  What does this tell us about physical objects in the areas where the plotted curve deviates the most from actual curve?  It takes higher order Fourier series components to describe it precisely.  I don't know beyond that.  Thanks for this video!

Two points I want to bring up: first, it seems to me that you kind of glossed over the parametrization part of your curve. It seems like you already have a specific speed you want to go at every point, and you just calculate the coefficients on this parametrization. My question is: isn’t it true that you can pick any parametrization you want, say constant speed for example, and find the coefficients for that, and have it draw out the same exact picture at a different speed?

Second, it appears that you’re going for perfection in the limit, because you’re taking the perfect curve and calculating the coefficients based on that curve. It seems to me that best approximation after 300 terms is a distinct goal with distinct coefficients. Sort of like how the Taylor polynomial expansion for sin x isn’t the best least-squares approximation for sin x over the interval [0,2pi]. How would one go about finding the best 300-term approximation, with a least-squares metric?
